1: An Unknown Source of al-Khwarizmi's Kitab şürat al-ard Miklós MARóTH Al-Khwarizmi composed his famous Kitab Șürat al-ard before 850 in the first half of the ninth century. There is no doubt that his description of the inhabited part of the world (seal gull) followed Ptolemy's Fetypapiki ipriynes. This basic observation is accepted by all scholars, but there are different views as to a number of details. One of the most interesting questions is, whether the Arabic text relies on the Greek original version directly, or else it is based on Syriac translation. The existence of a Syriac translation is attested by In al-Nadim. Writing on Ptolemy's Geography of the Inhabited Lands and Description of the Earth he states the followings: This book was in eight sections. Al-Kindi made a bad translation of it and then Thäbit [ibn Qurra] made an excellent Arabic translation. It is also extant in Syriac.' This book was in eight sections. Al-Kindi made a bad translation of it and then Thäbit [ibn Qurra] made an excellent Arabic translation. It is also extant in Syriac.' Al-Kindi and Thabit ibn Qurra were younger contemporaries of alKhwarizmi; consequently, it is not very likely that their translation of Ptolemy's Geography served as the main source for al-Khwarizmi's Kitah Strat al-ard. In this case one has to come to the conclusion that the unknown Syriac translation must have played an indispensable role in transmitting this piece of Greek geographic knowledge to the Arabs. 10: Having briefly reviewed the mountains of Central Asia I feel entitled to state that al-Khwärizmi's world-map drew on various sources. In addition to the Ptolemaic material some of them must have represented genuine Arabic knowledge obtained from the administration of the Islamic empire, as is evidenced by the original enumeration of cities;'" some of which must have had Syriac sources. This fact, i.e. the mixed character of the orthography, can account for the apparent hesitation in the literature about the acceptance of the theory of either a unique Greek or a Syriac source. PseudoAristotle, however, does not describe the mountains, nor does he mention the names of towns. Nevertheless, the method of description of the inhabited world in Jacobus's Hexaméron is identical to PseudoAristotle's method. Pseudo-Aristotle's De mundo, as I tried to point out in my recent works, must have been the handbook of geography in the ancient schools of rhetoric." This can be verified by the fact that it was rewritten in Latin by Apuleius," that, furthermore, it was known to the Fathers of the Church (as the names quoted above -Ambrosius, Chrysostomus, Lactantius- prove), and, lastly, that it was translated three times into Arabic.? The transcription of names and the text itself (omitted, inserted and misunderstood words) serve as evidence supporting our conviction that the Arabic text was translated from the Syriac version prepared by Sargis of Reshaina.? The first Arabic translation of this geographic treatise was made in the court of the Omayyad Caliph Hishām ibn 'Abd al-Malik as part of a novel in letters written in a Syrian school of rhetoric. These schools represented the institutes of higher education in the classical Antiquity and early Middle Ages. What was to be regarded as generally obligatory knowledge of a well-educated person in geography, was defined by the curricula of the schools of rhetoric which, in turn, taught the elements of philosophy and sciences on an elementary level. 13: After the Muslim conquest of the former Greek and Roman territories these schools of the ancient Greek rhetoric continued their activity, but in the course of time they turned into special Christian institutes of education serving as channels to convey Greek knowledge to the new Islamic countries. As our example proves, these schools played a certain role in the development of the Muslim sciences. The relationship between the ancient schools of rhetoric and Islamic civilization is perhaps an unknown domain of the history of the Islamic sciences which deserves to be investigated in the future. ABSTRACTS It has been a long debated question what was the ultimate source of alKhwarizmi's Kitab strat al-ard. The author of the present paper supports Nallino's thesis which says that al-Khwarizmi described al-Ma'mun's already existing world-map in his book. The right question is thus: what are the sources of al-Ma mün's map. In the article arguments are put forward to prove that Ptolemy's Geographike hyphegesis served as a basis for the world-map, but also newly acquired materials from the al-masālik wa'lmamalik literature have been inserted. The names of mountains, etc., from Ptolemy's description of world appear on al-Ma'mün's map and, accordingly, in al-Khwärizmi's book only in selection and based on Syriac translation. The selection follows the tradition of the philosophically inspired geographic literature used in the schools of Greek rhetoric, starting with Ps.-Aristotle's De mundo, continued by the Greek and Syriac Church Fathers and by the Arabic translation of De mundo in the correspondence ascribed to Aristotle and Alexander. The same tradition is still living in the geographic section of the philosophical encyclopaedia of the Ikhwān al-Safa'. *** Déterminer qui est la source ultime de le Kitāb şurat al-ard d'al-Khwarizmi est une question débattue depuis longtemps. Dans la présente contribution nous soutenons la thèse de Nallino selon laquelle al-Khwārizmi décrirait dans son livre une carte du monde déjà en possession d'al-Ma'mün. À ce point, la question devrait être posée dans les termes suivants : quelles sont les sources utilisées pour la carte d'al-Ma'mün ? Les sujets abordés ici visent à prouver que la Geographike hyphegesis de Ptolémée a servi de base pour une carte du monde, mais que de nouveaux matériaux appartenant à la littérature al-masalik wa'l-mamalik ont été également utilisés. Par exemple, les noms des montagnes etc., qui viennent de la description du monde de Ptolémée, apparaissent sur la carte d'al-Ma'mun et, par conséquent, dans le livre
14: d'al-Khwarizmi, dans une sélection basée sur une traduction syriaque. La sélection suit la tradition de la littérature géographique inspirée par les écoles philosophiques de la rhétorique grecque, en commençant par le De mundo du pseudo-Aristote à travers les Pères de l'Église grecque et syriaque et la traduction en arabe du De Mundo dans l'échange de lettres entre Aristote et Alexandre. La même tradition se trouve dans la section géographique de l'encyclopédie des Ikhwān al-Safa'. *** Determinare quale sia la fonte ultima del Kitāh sürat al-ard di al-Hwarizmi è questione lungamente dibattuta. Nel presente contributo si sostiene la tesi di Nallino secondo la quale al-Hwarizmi avrebbe descritto nel suo libro una mappa del mondo già in possesso di al-Ma'mún. A questo punto la domanda dovrebbe essere posta nei seguenti termini: quali furono le fonti utilizzate per la mappa di al-Ma'mün? Gli argomenti discussi nel presente contributo cercano di dimostrare che la Geographike hyphegesis di Tolomeo servi da base per la mappa del mondo ma che vennero utilizzati anche nuovi materiali provenienti dalla lettura al-masālik wa'l-mamalik. Ad esempio i nomi di montagne e simili, provenienti dalla descrizione del mondo di Tolomeo, compaiono sulla mappa di al-Ma'mun, e di conseguenza nel libro di al-Hwärizmi, in una selezione basata su una traduzione siriaca. La selezione segue la tradizione della letteratura geografica di ispirazione filosofica propria delle scuole di retorica greche, cominciata con il De mundo dello pseudo-Aristotele e continuata dai Padri della chiesa greci e siriaci e dalla traduzione araba del De mundo nello scambio epistolare che sarebbe intercorso tra Aristotele e Alessandro. La medesima tradizione la si ritrova nella sezione geografica dell'enciclopedia filosofica degli Ihwān al-Șafa'.
